Detailed Description

template<int numJoints> template class DefaultManipulator

Base class for open-architecture manipulators.

The class DefaultManipulator is the default implementation for open-architecture manipulators. The commonality of those manipulators is that they provide access to the torque controllers and some sort of position feedback. Hence, the servo control can be implemented in software. Specifically, this class utilizes an object of a derived class of ServoControl for this purpose.

The class DefaultManipulator uses templates of the number of joints. A derived class must specifiy the number of joints.

Example Program: See examples for the Puma560 class.

Member Enumeration Documentation

Vector< numJoints > getCurrentJointPosition<numJoints> ( )
 

Determines the current joint position of the manipulator. This often used function is probably easier to handle than the other versions of getCurrentJointPosition().

Returns:
A vector with the current joint position.(in radians)

Vector< numJoints > getDesiredJointPosition<numJoints> ( )
 

Gives the desired joint position of the manipulator.

Returns:
A vector with the desired joint position.(in radians)

Vector< numJoints > readJointPosition<numJoints> ( ) [virtual]
 

Reads the encoders and calculates the current joint position. This function is called in every control loop to update the joint position.

Reimplemented in Puma560.

Vector< numJoints > convertJointOutputToMotorOutput<numJoints> ( const Vector< numJoints >& jointOutput ) [virtual]
 

Converts a vector containing the joint output for all joints to the motor output. This output is usually a force or a torque. This class just assigns the joint output to the motor output vector. A derived class can reimplement this function to implement a different conversion (e.g., to take the coupling of joints into account).

Parameters:
jointOutput   The joint output vector(torque(N-m) or force(N)).
Returns:
The motor output vector(torque(N-m) or force(N)).

void reset ( ) [virtual]
 

This function resets the differentiators, integrators, filters and servo controller. A derived class must re-implement this function to reset any parameters specific to that class. When re-implemented in a derived class, the reset() function of the parent class must first be called in its implementation.

Reimplemented in Puma560.

void readGlobalConfiguration ( Config * config ) [virtual]
 

This function is used to read custom settings from the Robotic Platform configuration file.

Reimplemented from PhysicalObject.

Reimplemented in Puma560.

void setSimulationModeOn ( ) [virtual]
 

This function calls the function by the same name in the class PhysicalObject. Additionally it disconnects the association of an I/O board client from the manipulator.

Reimplemented from PhysicalObject.

void setSimulationModeOff ( ) [virtual]
 

This function calls the function by the same name in the class PhysicalObject. Additionally it connects the manipulator to the I/O board client.

Reimplemented from PhysicalObject.

Outputs information about the object to an output stream. This class adds hardware specific information of the manipulator such as the IOBoardServerName, channels for arm power bit, etc.

Parameters:
stream   Stream to output the information to.

Reimplemented from Manipulator.

void calibrateJointPosition ( const VectorBase<>& jointPosition ) [virtual]
 

Calibrates the manipulator by defining a certain position to be the current position that the manipulator is in. The new position overwrites the current position. This function should not be called while the manipulator is in movement. When reimplementing this function, a derived class must assure that using this function does not result in undesired movements of the manipulator, i.e. any connected servo control must be informed about the calibration as well as trajectory generators.

Parameters:
jointPosition   New manipulator joint position(radians).

Reimplemented from Manipulator.

Reimplemented in Puma560.

void setDesiredJointPosition ( const VectorBase<>& desiredJointPosition ) [virtual]
 

Sets a setpoint for the joint position. Note that this function must not be used to move the manipulator to a target position; rather, this function must be called at a certain frequency to create a smooth trajectory. To move the manipulator to a target position, a trajectory generator must be used. To avoid exceeding torque limits, the desired joint position must be heavily filtered so that it's rate of change is low enough.

Parameters:
desiredJointPosition   The desired joint position(radians).

Reimplemented from Manipulator.

void setDesiredEndEffectorTransform ( Transform & desiredEndEffectorTransform ) [virtual]
 

Sets a setpoint for the end-effector transform. Note that this function must not be used to move the manipulator to a target position; rather, this function must be called at a certain frequency to create a smooth trajectory. To move the manipulator to a target position, a trajectory generator must be used.

Reimplemented from Manipulator.

void setTrajectoryGenerator ( TrajectoryGenerator & trajectoryGenerator ) [virtual]
 

Associates a trajectory generator with the manipulator. The manipulator object uses this trajectory generator to determine desired trajectory for the manipulator.

This class calls the function of the same name in the parent Manipulator class where it stores an internal pointer that can be retrieved with getTrajectoryGenerator() and also calls the reset() function of the trajectory generator. Additionally the trajectory filter cut-off frequency is set to twice the sample rate of the trajectory generator.

If a derived class implements this function it should first call the setTrajectoryGenerator() function of the parent class then add additional functionality.

Parameters:
trajectoryGenerator   A pointer to an object of a class that is derived from the class TrajectoryGenerator.

Reimplemented from Manipulator.

void enableArmPower ( ) [virtual]
 

Enables the arm power of the manipulator. The arm power is enabled by default when the object is being constructed.

Note that some manipulators don't enable the arm power immediately (e.g., a call to enableArmPower() does not result in an immediate enabling of the arm power), for example, because they need user intervention (e.g., pressing the arm power button). Hence, use the function isArmPowerEnabled() to check if the arm power has really been enabled yet.

Reimplemented from Manipulator.

void disableArmPower ( ) [virtual]
 

Disables the arm power of the manipulator. The arm power is disabled automatically when the object is being deleted or shutdown.

Note that some manipulators don't disable the arm power immediately (e.g., the WAM might go into a damping mode and wait until the arm drops slowly to a stable position). Hence, use the function isArmPowerEnabled() to check if the arm power has really been disabled yet.

Reimplemented from Manipulator.

bool isArmPowerEnabled ( ) [virtual]
 

Determines if the arm power is currently enabled.

Returns:
true: The arm power is enabled, false: The arm power is disabled.

Reimplemented from Manipulator.

VectorBase * createJointVector ( ) [virtual]
 

Creates a vector that has as many elements as the manipulator has joints. The vector is allocated with "new", hence, it needs to be deleted with "delete" by the user.

Returns:
A pointer to the vector.

Reimplemented from Manipulator.

void setTeachModeOn ( ) [virtual]
 

Switches to the teach mode of the manipulator. For the default manipulator, this is equivalent to enabling gravity compensation and disabling the servo control.

Reimplemented from Manipulator.

void setTeachModeOff ( ) [virtual]
 

Leaves the teach mode and goes back to normal control mode.

Reimplemented from Manipulator.

bool isTeachModeOn ( ) [virtual]
 

Determines if the manipulator is in teach mode.

Returns:
true: The manipulator is in teach mode, false: The manipulator is in normal control mode.

Reimplemented from Manipulator.

void setJointControlOutput ( const VectorBase<>& controlOutput ) [virtual]
 

Sets the current control output that is sent to the manipulator's joints. The control output is converted into motor space and then output to the D/A converters of the I/O board.

Parameters:
controlOutput   A vector containing the current control output (e.g., the torque for revolute joints) that should be applied to the links.

Reimplemented from OpenArchitectureManipulator.

void setJointControlOutput ( int jointnumber,
double controlOutput ) [virtual]
 

Sets the current control output of a specified joint. The control output is converted into motor space and then output to the D/A converters of the I/O board.

Parameters:
jointNumber   The joint to which the control output is sent.
controlOutput   The current control output to the joint (e.g., the torque for revolute joints)

Reimplemented from OpenArchitectureManipulator.

void getJointControlOutput ( VectorBase<>& controlOutput ) [virtual]
 

Determines the current control output that is sent to the manipulator's joints.

Parameters:
controlOutput   A vector containing the current control output (e.g., the torque for revolute joints) for all links.

Reimplemented from OpenArchitectureManipulator.

double getControlPeriod ( ) [virtual]
 

Returns the control period of the Qmotor Control Program associated with the manipulator.

Reimplemented from OpenArchitectureManipulator.

void setGravityCompensationOn ( ) [virtual]
 

Enables the gravity compensation. Note that the gravity compensation works in addition to the associated servo control, i.e., the control output of the servo control and the gravity compensation are added.

If a derived class reimplements this function, it should first call the setGravityCompensationOn() of the parent class.

void setGravityCompensationOff ( ) [virtual]
 

Disables the gravity compensation.

If a derived class reimplements this function, it should first call the setGravityCompensationOff() of the parent class.

bool isGravityCompensationOn ( )
 

Determines if the gravity compensation is enabled.

Returns:
true: Gravity compensation is enabled
false: Gravity compensation is disabled.

void setFrictionCompensationOn ( ) [virtual]
 

Enables the friction compensation. Note that friction compensation works in addition to the associated servo control, i.e., the control output of the servo control and the friction compensation are added. Note that the user will not be be able to enable the friction compensation if the manipulator is not associated with a servo control, or if this function is called before servo control is set and enabled (no error messages are output in this case).

If a derived class reimplements this function, it should first call the setFrictionCompensationOn() of the parent class.

void setFrictionCompensationOff ( ) [virtual]
 

Disables the friction compensation.

If a derived class reimplements this function, it should first call the setFrictionCompensationOff() of the parent class.

bool isFrictionCompensationOn ( )
 

Determines if the friction compensation is enabled.

Returns:
true: friction compensation is enabled
false: friction compensation is disabled.

void setDynamicSimulationOn ( )
 

Switches the system into dynamic simulation mode. In this mode, the simulation is carried out using actual dynamic equations for the manipulator.

void setDynamicSimulationOff ( )
 

Switches off dynamic siimulation mode.

bool isDynamicSimulationOn ( )
 

Determines if dynamic simulation mode is enabled.

void startShutdown ( ) [virtual]
 

This function starts the shutdown process for the manipulator. It calls the shutdown function of the parent class and performs the necessary actions to shut down the hardware.

Reimplemented from RoboticObject.

int enterControl ( ) [virtual]
 

Called before the configuration is loaded. Used to register variables and allocate memory

Returns:
0: loading the control was successful non-zero : error occurred

Reimplemented from ControlProgram.

int startControl ( ) [virtual]
 

Called each time the control is started (eg. the START button is pushed).

Returns:
0: successful initialization of parameters. non-zero : error occurred

Reimplemented from ControlProgram.

int stopControl ( ) [virtual]
 

Called at the end of each control run.

Returns:
0: control program stopped successfully. non-zero : error occurred

Reimplemented from ControlProgram.

int control ( ) [virtual]
 

Main control function. Called each time through the control loop.

Returns:
0: continue control execution non-zero : error occurred

Reimplemented from ControlProgram.

char * messageBuffer ) [virtual]
 

Called when a message that is not from the Timer server arrives. This allows you to receive QNX message from other processes. This function is optional.

Returns:
0: proceed with control if control is running. non-zero : error occurred
